EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

CITY OF CHICKASHA 

WATER TREATMENT PLANT

CHICKASHA OKLAHOMA

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



The City of Chickasha Water Treatment Plant has prepared and implemented a Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions of 40 CFR part 68 to prevent Chlorine exposure to facility staff and members of the community, as well as the environment. This RMP encompasses all the elements of the Risk Management Program.  Accidental release, prevention, and emergency response policies at the Chickasha Water Treatment Plant (WTP) emphasize safety, training, and maintenance.



The WTP is located in Chickasha, Oklahoma, at or near Latitude N. 35.03.48 and a Longitude W. 97.55.39.  Chlorine is used to disinfect filtered water to make potable water safe for consumption. The WTP treats on average 3 Million Gallons a Day (MGD).  The WTP is designed to treat up to 6MGD.  The WTP will have the maximum of 16,000lbs of chlorine on-site at any one time.  Chlorine is stored in 1-ton cylinders with 2-cylinders on process and up to 6-cylinders on standby.  Chlorine is drawn from the cylinders in a gaseous state.



The chlorine cylinders and feed systems are checked at least twice daily for leaks and feed rates.  The preventative maintenance program has numerous operator and maintenance checks to ensure full and proper operation.



A worst-case release scenario has been estimated, per EPA guidance, to provide the greatest distance in any direction to the established toxic endpoint.  The worst-case release quantity, established by the regulations, is the greatest amount of chlorine held in a single vessel.  The WTP's worst-case release scenario is 1 Ton (2,000lbs).  In accordance with 40CFR section 68.25, the chlorine gas will be released at a rate of 200lbs per minute and will continue for ten minutes.



No administrative controls or active mitigation measures were included for the worst-case release scenario.  Tables from the EPA and

Chemical Emergency Preparedness and Prevention Office (CEPPO) Risk Management Program Guidance for Water Treatment Plants were used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario, at a distance of 1.3 miles. 



The five-year accident history was evaluated to determine a likely alternative release scenario.  The WTP has not has an incident within the last five (5) years.



USW Utility Group has developed Accidental Release Response and Prevention Programs in the form of a Risk Management Plan, an Emergency Action Plan, training with local Emergency Responders, Operator training, Operator inspections of the chlorine system, and a Preventative Maintenance Program.



USW Utility Group will conduct training with local Emergency Responders (Chickasha Fire Department) more frequently. Operators will be trained and drills conducted as per the WTP's RMP.
